name: imidodicarbonimidic diamide, n-(4-chlorophenyl)-

The presence of the chloro substituent on the phenyl ring tends to increase melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and potential for intermolecular interactions such as dipole-dipole interactions; chloro substituent: +50 degrees. The imidodicarbonimidic diamide structure is similar to that of a triazine ring, which has a high melting point due to the rigidity of the ring system and strong nitrogen-nitrogen double bonds; this function can be estimated to contribute: +60 degrees. Lastly, there is an additional isopropyl group (C(C)C), which increases the overall molecular mass and can provide some additional van der Waals interactions, but due to its branched nature it may not significantly raise the melting point; isopropyl group: +5 degrees. Combining these effects, we can predict the melting point of the target compound.
